This school year the Montgomery County Department of Health and Human Services partnered with the Pottstown Middle School to implement a share table. Share tables help reduce food waste in schools while promoting an increase in nutritious foods to other students. Due to COVID-19, the share table program is currently postponed.

However, 40% of food that's wasted in the U.S. occurs right at home. That's why MCOPH has decided to share education and resources on ways to prevent food waste at home. Every Wednesday, check in right here on our Facebook page for #WasteLessWednesdays where you’ll find recipes and tips to reduce waste in your kitchen! This program was funded by the PA Department of Health

Will someone have to sit down with my child for hours during the day while they complete classwork?" the answer is No! Our virtual program is asynchronous, meaning it's flexible learning, built to work around your child's needs and the schedule of your family.

Watch the short video below for important FAQ's on our VAL program to help you decide what's best for your student.

Want to apply or learn more? Visit the link below

The alarm system was activated, students and staff were relocated to the middle school. Pottstown fire trucks and Fire Marshall responded immediately and after investigation, the building was cleared for the return of students and staff. Lunch and class schedules were adjusted and regular activity resumed at 12:15. A special thanks to our first responders who reacted to ensure the safety of all and to our students and staff for following our emergency procedures. Our maintenance crew has addressed the mechanical problem to ensure everyone is safe.

post_text: Pottstown Middle School music program was well represented at the 64th Annual Inter-County Band Festival. Band members participating were; Layla Bearden (flute), Brittany Endy (flute), Collin Mattis (clarinet), Tyler Broughton (tenor saxophone), Makenna Franey (trumpet), Aiden Kancianic (baritone) and Mehki Jenkins-Glover (percussion). The following schools to participate were: Arcola, OJR, Perkiomen Valley East & West, Spring Ford, Boyertown East & West, Phoenixville, Pottsgrove, Pottstown, Upper Perkiomen. Each band director conducts a piece with the band. The concert which comes together in only 3 rehearsals ended the night with John Phillip Sousa's "The Liberty Bell March," arranged by Jay Bocook.

Students in Ms. Miller's Anatomy & Physiology class who have dreams of careers in the medical and health fields did some hands-on learning of anatomy by dissecting a fetal pig.
You can read about anatomy in textbooks, but until you have actually explored and located organs in a body, you can not appreciate the miracle of a living organism. The project required students to be able to collaborate and communicate in order to locate and study organs and the role they play in body functions. The next surgeon may very well have gotten their start in Ms.Miller's class!

post_text: With a team roster that numbers 35, the largest in many years, the Trojan wrestling team, that has only three seniors on the squad are learning a lot of lessons about what it takes to first survive and then be able to win on the mat. With a 1-4 record they entered the Ralph Wetzel Individual Tournament and came away from the 2 day, 7 mats, 35 teams and over 450 wrestlers event with a better understanding of what they must do to be successful. No Trojan medaled in the varsity division. Demond Thomposn won three bouts all by pin in 31 seconds,37 and 1:27 before two losses dropped him out of the medal round. Jared Hewitt, Devon Green, Josiah Wiggins and Zack Griffin all picked up wins before being eliminated. Hewitt and Justice Harris lost in two very close overtime bouts. In a new all female division , Julianna Figeroa and Mia Bumbarger both went undefeated earning three pins in four bouts. The young Trojans gained a lot of experience and confidence in the JV Division winning 29 bouts lead by Diego Jamie placing 2nd and Travis Harvey taking 3rd.

post_text: PHS Health Occupation students under the leadership of their teacher Mrs. Michaela Johnson, received some hands on learning while assisting in the school's annual Fall blood drive. The drive is done in partnership with the Miller-Keystone Blood Center. Students were responsible for the organization of the event and assisted in the collection of life saving units of blood. The drive was a great success and exceeded the goal of 37 units by collecting 40 units from the 56 students and staff who registered to donate. It is estimated that the blood collected will be able to help in saving 120 lives. Mrs Johnson said “I am very proud of our students and staff who continually show their leadership in organizing this lifesaving event and willingness to give of themselves to help those in need.” Share the news! Proud to be from Pottstown

Before receiving this technology, Pottstown’s Auto Tech was the only program in the area without an alignment rack. Now, they’re the only school in the area with the advanced system! The alignment rack will not only boost the students’ academic experience; it will give them the opportunity to develop directly transferable skills to the automotive industry. Pottstown’s CTE programs give students the unique opportunity to learn hands on skills for a variety of career driven industry’s.
